title: Managing a Chronic Diabetic Foot Ulcer in a Retired Carpenter
clinical_history: Mr. John Matthews is a 68-year-old retired carpenter who presents with a non-healing ulcer on the plantar aspect of his right foot, noted for the last 6 weeks. The ulcer began as a small blister after walking in ill-fitting shoes but has progressively worsened despite basic wound care. John reports mild to moderate pain surrounding the ulcer, particularly at the ball of his foot, but admits to significant numbness and tingling in his feet for several years. On examination, there is a 3cm x 2cm ulcer with peri-wound erythema at the first metatarsal head. He ambulates with an antalgic gait, and inspection reveals atrophy of the intrinsic foot muscles and a collapsed longitudinal arch. Pulses are diminished but palpable. There is mild swelling, but no systemic symptoms.

nprs.affected_area: plantar aspect, around the first metatarsal head (right foot)
diffuse burning and tingling in the foot (neuropathic complaint)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking, standing, wearing tight or closed-toe footwear, exposure to cold, and manipulation of the ulcer. Blood sugar spikes are associated with worsening symptoms.
picture: [Insert image depicting ulcer at plantar aspect of the right first metatarsal head, with surrounding erythema and muscle atrophy in the foot.]
easing_factors: Resting and elevating the foot, wearing off-loading sandals, maintaining good glycemic control, local wound dressing changes, and mild analgesics.
past_history: Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 14 years ago, with poor glycemic control (HbA1c 8.6%). Previous episode of a callus and superficial ulcer on the left heel two years ago that resolved with conservative management. Long-standing peripheral neuropathy.
medical_history: Hypertension, hyperlipidemia, mild chronic kidney disease (eGFR 58 ml/min/1.73m2). No history of smoking but has a 30-year occupational exposure to hand tools and mild solvent inhalation.
medications: Metformin 1000mg BID, Lisinopril 10mg QD, Atorvastatin 20mg QD, Gabapentin 300mg BID (for neuropathic symptoms), Aspirin 81mg QD.
personal_history: Lives with his wife in a single-story home. Retired from carpentry three years ago. Walks daily but has reduced activity due to foot pain. Enjoys gardening and woodworking on a hobby basis.
imaging: Recent foot X-ray showed no evidence of osteomyelitis, though mild degenerative changes present. No Charcot foot changes seen.
